Name: Bluff or Buff
Description: A bone-tickling, hilarious adult game of sexy revelation and high-stakes faking. Contains 124 Bluff or Buff cards, 16 playing chips, score pad, and pencil. For 2 to 8 players.

Name: Nice or Nasty?
Description: The adult sexy slang game for word freaks! Contains 104 Nice or Nasty cards, 1 Nice or Nasty playing board, 8 pawns, 8 pads, and 8 pencils. For 2 to 8 players.

Name: Bare with Me
Description:
Players reveal their sexy reasoning or complete "pointed" sentence stems in their own words. For instance, do you know what your lover or friends would write if asked to list 2 reasons for having sex on the first date? Or how would they complete the sentence "If sex was playground equipment, I'd be..." or "You know I'm feeling horny when..."? Winning the game is easy: be the first player to collect a token from each of the other players by correctly guessing their answer!

The game where you  "Bare" more than your soul! Includes 64 game chips, 80 game cards, 1 die, 8 pads, 8 pencils and rule sheet. For 3-8 players.

Name: Pose & Disclose
Description: The Scandalous game for show-offs and posers! Includes 160 game cards, 2 dice, rule sheet. For 2 or more players.

Name: Steamy Scenarios
Description: The ultimate game of "What If?" Includes game board, 104 game cards, 8 game pieces, answer pad, 8 pencils and rule sheet. For 4 or more players.

Name: Stacked
Description: The titillating game of strategy and conquest! Includes game board, 60 playing pieces, rule sheet. For 2 or more players.

Name: Throws of Passion
Description: The hilarious  'Love Positions'  Dice Game. Includes male and female dice, 6 'positions' cards, score pad, rule booklet, pencils and storage pouch. For 2 or more players.

Name: Fortune Maker
Description:
From the box: "The action packed stock market game for 2 to 6 players".

On a board with 2 tracks the players move around the outer track using a d6, landing on squares that let them buy/sell shares, move the share index or gain/lose money.

The inner track (share index) indicates how share prices are altering.

Players try to buy low and sell high, gaining dividends over time.  If you get it wrong, you're bankrupt and out of the game.

The game ends when all but 1 player is eliminated or after a set period of time, the winner is the player with the greatest value of shares and money combined.

Name: Shocking Memory
Description:
Similar to the game Simon, Shocking Memory has eight panels instead of four and you get shocked if you make a mistake. This game is not intended for small children or persons with heart conditions.

From the publisher's website:
Put your memory to the test. Repeat the sequence of lights and sounds. Each round gets a little longer and harder. If you can't remember the sequence; thats too bad, we're so sad...ouch! With three speeds even the best players will be sweating.

Name: Trylogy (The Twin Cities)
Description: Tryology appears to be a combination of trivia and abstract strategy.  Shipped in a triangular box, just like another Osobo title Triopoly.  They also seemed to love to produce black components, as evidenced by Tryology, Triopoly and Beverly Hills.

Name: Red Dwarf: The Card Game
Description: Red Dwarf: The Card Game is a print and play card game based on the BBC sitcom Red Dwarf. Cards are taken directly from the TV show.

Name: Tricky Town
Description: Board game with a trick-or-treat theme.  Each player has four pieces representing members of a family (mom, dad, boy, girl), and a deck of cards used to determine movement.  All players flip a card simultaneously, with order of movement determined by characters on the cards.  Players move the number of spaces indicated by the number on a card; odd numbers move only one piece, even numbers can be split evenly between two pieces.  Spaces on the board result in the gain or loss of treats (victory points).  Players can also acquire "trick or treat" cards which can be played for extra movement.  Movement is restricted by a rule that a child may never be more than five spaces away from a parent.  There are short cuts that may be taken only by a parent and child together.

Name: World Bowling Tour
Description:
From rules:  "As a Pro Bowler, you enjoy being on tour, playing tournaments, earning your living by doing what you enjoy most...bowling.  You have as a goal, gaining a reputation as a top professional bowler and insuring that you can always earn a living through bowling."

Players move bowling pin shaped pawns on a track that looks like a bowling score sheet, participating in tournaments as they go, collecting money for setting records or meeting sponsors, paying money for purchases or hospital bills, investing in pro shops, and sometimes falling into slumps.  For tournament play, a separate pawn shaped like a bowing ball moves along a separate tournament track that looks like a bowling ball knocking down two pins.

To win, players need to collect money and place first in at least one tournament.

The box cover pictures Don Carter and Paula Sperber, who endorse the game and were apparently popular bowlers back in the day.

Name: El Enigma de la Pirámide
Description:
The players begin their way through the Labyrinth, creating a route for  themselves while trying to obstruct the paths of other players.
In the labyrinth which they are creating there are two types of tiles, blue and orange. In the blue ones mummies appear and must be dealt with.
When the players eventually cross the Labyrinth, they begin their way across the Shrine. There, they must confront not only more mummies but also rocks that fall. Both rocks and   mummies cause a player to be wounded. The wounds are shown on the cardboard that each player has. When  a player receives three wounds, the player dies  and is out of the game.
After one reaches the Shrine there is a Treasure. The fist player to get it wins the game.

Name: Trio
Description: Trio is a challenging and tactical game for children. In this game you have to move scoops of ice cream around on the board, and try to place three scoops on top of each other in the order shown on your 2 cards. Every time you succeed you win a card. You can also block the other players, by placing a cherry on top of your scoops. Win the most cards, and you will win the game.

Name: Pirat Über Bord
Description: The players try to place their pirates and barrels on the wobbly ship without knocking down the other pirates. A spinner is used to decide on what level the pieces should be placed.

Name: Revenge
Description:
Revenge is a collection of rules specifically written for warfare in the Middle Ages. From the Dark Ages to the rise of gunpowder, war was the sport of nobles who knew that virtue, leadership, and courage were the only principles of war.

Revenge contains three sets of rules each emphasizing a romanticized view of an aspect of medieval battle: Deus Vult is for field battles, Into the Breach for sieges and Sluys for naval warfare.

Deus Vult is designed for 15mm miniatures, each model representing 20 men, but can be easily scaled for use with 25mm miniatures. Meanwhile, Into the Breach is designed for 25mm miniatures representing 5 men each. Sluys is intended for 1:100 scale ship models and 15mm miniatures.

There exists also a supplement, "The Normans", which contains several scenarios for Revenge, but no new rules.

Name: Beware the Spider
Description:
The game uses a similar mechanic to Operation and takes two C-cell batteries.

The red molded plastic game base has a silver conductive web on which various plastic critters are placed.  A foam spider is situated menacingly next to the web in its allocated position over a small hole, which contains a small mechanical lever-type apparatus inside.

Each turn, players attempt to remove a critter from the web with a pronged device that is connected to the board with a wire.  If the surface of the web is touched with this, the circuit is completed, the mechanism in the hole beneath the spider is activated and the spider is launched.  Any player disturbing the spider must replace the critter they were trying to get.

The player collecting the most critters from the web without disturbing the spider (touching the web with the pronged device) is the winner.

Name: Bop the Beetle
Description:
This old game comes in a huge box (20" x 13" x 5").  It consists of five components only - a large plastic clam-like frog with identical halves almost 12" long and wide; two thick plastic oval beetles 4" x 6" and two 20" long solid plastic tubes (the 'boppers').  The two halves of the frog are joined by a hinge at the rear which causes the frog to lock in an open position when set.

The beetles are placed on the ground an equal and agreed distance away from the set frog and must be 'bopped' into the frog using the plastic tubes provided.   This is accomplished by whacking the plastic tube on an edge of the beetle, causing it to fly up in the air.  The first player to successfully bop their beetle into the frog causes the frog to snap shut and wins the game.

Name: Mark Three
Description:
IDEAL's treatment of tic-tac-toe enclosed in a large 18" square box.

The large plastic gameboard consists of four gently sloping ramps which extend upward from each side of a tic-tac-toe grid.  There is a circular hole in the center of each grid segment to accept players' discs.

Each player is given eight plastic discs of their chosen color and a device to release the discs (basically a circular piece of plastic with a raised slit) down their particular ramp.  A turn consists of aiming a disc and releasing it down the ramp.  Discs that fail to come to rest completely within a hole are removed from the board and used later if required.  Only the top disc showing in any given hole counts in gameplay.

The first player to land three of their discs in holes so that they form a straight row in any direction is the winner.

Name: Bee Bopper
Description:
"BOP UP YOUR BEE BOP, WHEN THE SPINNER POINTS TO YOU...
I'LL TRY TO CATCH YOUR BEE AND WIN A CHIP OR TWO"

"Get ready!  Get set!  Play BEE BOPPER!  One player bops their bee when the spinner points to their color.  To win chips, opponents try to trap the bee before it is bopped, or catch the bee in their net after it is bopped.  Who's the best BEE BOPPER? ...invite the gang around to find out!"

Players must try to increase their initial complement of ten chips to twenty by catching or trapping opponent's bees with their net.  The first to do so is the winner.

The game comes in a large colorful box (16" x 14" x 3") with four nets, four bees, four bopping devices, a spinner and a supply of chips.  Apart from the cardboard spinner base, all components are plastic.

Name: Tombstones n' Tumbleweeds
Description:
A character driven Western tabletop wargame by Game Werks. Players act out gunfights and other "Old West" scenarios involving a handful of distinct characters in miniature.
This game borrows many mechanics from other games, and thoughtfully blends them together for a easy to follow, yet comprehensive, miniatures game. 
Like Mordheim, players are able to advance their characters, and play through many one off, or linked scenarios. Scale is 25mm.
Rulebook is available in print format, as well as a PDF download through RPGNow.com and Wargaming Online.

Name: Count Dino's Number Marathon
Description: Each player tries to move his herd of dinosaurs across the finish line first by rolling dice and counting. A player chooses a herd (all Stegasauruses or Dimetrodons or T. Rexes or Triceratops, etc. Each dinosaur in a herd is a different color: red, yellow, green, and purple. A player rolls four dice and puts them in any order he wishes so that they make a four-digit number. Then he moves each dinosaur along a separate colored path: the red dinosaur moves by the thousands digits, the yellow dinosaur moves by the hundreds digits, and so on. Then the next herd of dinosaurs starts their trek on the path to the finish line. Game variations allow for showdowns, "Dino Math Action," and "Prehistoric Problem Solving" for older children.

Name: The Road Runner Game
Description:
The Road Runner Game consists of a deck of cards and 8 flat cardboard cutout figures of The Road Runner and 1 Wile E. Coyote figure, both characters from the Warner Brothers cartoons.

The cards are numbered and have brightly colored and patterned backgrounds (one background per set of numbered cards).  The cutouts are about 10 inches tall.

The Road Runner and Coyote cutouts are placed in the center of the table.  One less Road Runner than there are number of people playing are used.

The players try to collect a full set of numbered cards.  The first one to do so lays his cards down and grabs a Road Runner figure.  Everyone else grabs a figure as quickly as possible.  The last person to grab a cutout (or perhaps a faster person, but one who grabbed the wrong figure) gets the Coyote.

Name: Professor Noggin's Countries of the World
Description: For those who know plenty about their own country, but want to learn about other areas of the world, Professor Noggin offers a trivia game on various countries, and their flags, capitals, languages, traditions, as well as the animals and people who inhabit them.

Name: Professor Noggin's Countries of the World 2
Description: A companion game to the original Countries of the World card game. Learn more facts about lesser known countries and the continents they belong to.

Name: Professor Noggin's Ancient Civilizations
Description: Professor Noggin steps back in time to explore lost but not forgotten civilizations. Discover facts about ancient places, philosophers, buildings, clothing, arts, and empires on a trivia-filled journey of discovery.

Name: Professor Noggin's Medieval Times
Description: What did the Magna Carta do for us? Who was Joan of Arc? How did one avoid being burned as a witch? Learn the answers as you travel back in time to a world of knights, battles, castles and cathedrals.

Name: Professor Noggin's Creatures of Myth & Legend
Description: Gryphons, basilisks and phoenixes all existed before Harry Potter. Learn about these mythical creatures and explore the science, religious beliefs and cultures that created them.

Name: Professor Noggin's Earth Science
Description:
Learn about the volcanoes, thunderstorms, and the crust of the earth as Professor Noggin tests your knowledge on Earth Science.

Card topics include:
Continental Drift
Rivers and Streams
Oceans_&_Seas
Peninsulas
Mountains
Sedimentary Rocks
Lakes & Ponds
Prairies
Canyons

Atmosphere

Hurricanes
Tornadoes
Weather Forecasting

Name: Professor Noggin's  Famous Inventions
Description:
The world is made up of famous inventions. Professor Noggin looks throughout history to quiz you on how the most prominent inventions were made, and who made them.

Card.topics.include:
Architecture_&_Construction
Automobiles
Aviation
Bicycles
Clothing Textiles
Computers

Food & Cooking

Name: Professor Noggin's Wonders of Science
Description:
Professor Noggin takes Science out of the classroom and into this entertaining trivia game. See what you know, and learn surprising new facts as you go. Wonders of Science will create science wonderment for all who play.

Card.topics.include:
Birds & Fish
Cells
Compass
Earth
Energy
Electricity
Environment

Force
Gases

Water
Weather

Name: Professor Noggin's American Revolution
Description:
Professor Noggin offers a game covering the American Revolution, a happening that shaped the modern United States of America. No other children's game uncovers the significant events with such fresh, enlightening trivia facts.

Card topics include:
Famous Women
George Washington
Benjamin Franklin
Life Before the War
The War Starts
Stamp Act
African Americans
Native Americans
The 13 Colonies
Declaration_of_Independence
French and Indian War

The Hardships of War
Weapons and Technology
Flags
Independence
The War Ends
Treaty of Paris
Life after the Revolution
Who were the Patriots?

Name: Professor Noggin's Civil War
Description:
From the Publisher's website:
Keeping in mind that in order to know which way we are headed, we need to know where we've been, this game has trivia on the battles, soldiers, and different aspects of the American Civil War.

Professor Noggin's series of educational games encourages kids to learn interesting facts about their favorite subjects. Each of the thirty game cards combines trivia, true or false, and multiple choice questions.
A special three-numbered die is included which creates interaction and promotes communications between players. Easy and hard levels keep kids interested and challenged - while of having fun!

Card topics include:
Famous Military Leaders
The Civil War Starts
Confederate States of
America
Before the Civil War
Raising Armies
Uncle Tom's Cabin
African Americans during the War
Jefferson Davis
Fun and Games
Ford Theater

Battle of Gettysburg

Abraham Lincoln

Rebuilding After the War
Nursing the Wounded
Siege of Vicksburg
Life_as_a_Confederate Soldier
Famous Battles
Famous Women
The Underground Railroad
Food and Agriculture
The Civil War Ends
Technology
Heroes of the Civil War
Ulysses S. Grant and Robert E. Lee
Freedom
Ships and Boats

Name: Professor Noggin's Freshwater Life in North America
Description:
Everything young naturalists need to know about life in the ponds, lakes and rivers of North America. Learn about River Otter, Wood Ducks, Mosquitoes, and Snapping Turtles.

Alligators
Amphibians

Birds

Whirligigs

Name: Professor Noggin's Pets
Description:
Puppies, kittens, lizards, and turtles are just a few of the popular pets that children long to adopt. Discover interesting facts about common pets, and learn about the proper care these pets need from their human parents.

Name: Professor Noggin's Wildlife Safari
Description:
Professor Noggin embarks on an expedition of the most colorful, exciting animals in the world, such as lions, zebras, and elephants. The diversity of wildlife is tremendous in this adventurous game of the natural world.

Name: Professor Noggin's Reptiles & Amphibians
Description:
Professor Noggin explores some of the longest-surviving animals on earth. Lizards, snakes and crocodilians are just a few of the scaly, cold-blooded species that are investigated in this game.

Sand Viper

Name: Professor Noggin's National Parks
Description:
Professor Noggin travels around to develop a game that celebrates our beloved parks, which have helped preserve history, heritage, and the natural beauty of North America for the enjoyment of all its citizens.

Card topics include:
Eastern Woodland Parks
Park Safety
First Peoples Heritage

Name: Professor Noggin's Life on the Farm
Description:
Cultivate your mind with trivia questions from Professor Noggin’s Life on the Farm. Topics range from all aspects of farm life, including animals, plants, and machines.

Card topics include:
Apples
Berries
Chickens
Corn
Cotton

Name: Professor Noggin's  Birds of North America
Description:
Test your knowledge on the warm-blooded, egg-laying, feathered vertebrates more commonly known as birds. Just because they all have wings doesn’t mean they’re all the same. In fact, Professor Noggin will give you a true bird’s eye view of what kinds of differences are found in these incredible creatures.

Card topics include:
American_Kestrel
American Swallow-tailed Kite
Anhinga
Barn Swallow
Barn Owl
Blackbirds
Blue Jay

Name: Professor Noggin's Dinosaur
Description:
These prehistoric creatures will come to life in this game of frightening facts and deadly discoveries. Find out everything you wanted know to know about Dinosaurs, including what they ate, how big they grew, and how they defended themselves.

Card topics include:
Allosaurus
Archaeopteryx

Name: Professor Noggin's Insects and Spiders
Description:
Insects and Spiders are some of nature’s tiniest wonders. Learn what they eat, where they live, and what makes them unique in this creepy, crawly Professor Noggin game that is guaranteed to keep you swarming with excitement.

Ants
Black Widow Spider
Dangerous Insects
Dragonflies
Earthworms

Name: Professor Noggin's Outer Space
Description:
Professor Noggin delves deep into Outer Space, exploring plants, starts, and solar systems. Explore the cosmos in this challenging trivia game that will have you guessing about everything under the sun, and some things over it.

Card.topics.include:
Asteroids
Astronaut
Comets
Crater
Earth
Earth’s Moon
Eclipse
Galaxy
Galileo

Hubble
Jupiter
Mars

Saturn V Rocket
Solar System
Space Shuttle

Stars
(Part 1)
Stars
(Part 2)
Sun
Telescopes
Uranus
Venus

Name: Who Did It...?
Description:
Sharpen your pencils and prepare to test your wits. In a roller coaster ride aboard the Oriental Express a crime has been committed which only you can solve! Play the role of a famous detective - you could be Sheerluck Homes or Ivan Inkling! It's a hectic race from carriage to carriage as you seek clues and try to fit the missing pieces of the puzzle together.
Instant family fun, this captivating board game will thrill and entertain you as you rush to reveal who it was that dun the dastardly deed!

Contents :  5 foot lay out of a steam train game board, counters, pencils, mystery card deck, score pad, die, rules

Name: Chattabox
Description: In this fun, teasing race game, players attempt to play their cards while calling out solutions to given topics.

Name: Rhyme Thyme
Description: Rhyme Thyme is a fast-action matching game that will have you racing to get rid of your cards first. Spot a rhyme in another player's hand and be the first to call out the match. You will need keen eyes and fast hands to "catch the match" in this game.

Name: Beam Me Up
Description:
From publisher:

It's the Annual Alien Conference and the aliens are stuck on the moon without transportation. This is your chance to take an alien home! Maybe not your home... but it's your job to get the aliens back to their home planets. In this trick-taking card game the highest card wins the round. Call out "Beam Me Up" when you have collected three aliens from the same home planet and a Space Racer will come to the rescue. The player who send the most aliens home by the end of the game wins the title of Star Space Traffic Controller!

The game is played in rounds with each player trying to win tricks by playing the highest numbered card. For every trick won, the player who played the highest card gets to choose 1 card from the trick to keep and add to his Beam Me Up line. The object is to get 3 cards with matching elementals in your Beam Me Up line so a Space Racer can be launched to come and transport the aliens home.

Name: Camper Damper
Description:
From publisher:
It's time for a trip to the woods in this fun game where players scramble to complete their camping trips. Each game is different as you collect food, fun and shelter, while other campers try to sabotage your fun with Camper Dampers. Dodge all sorts of trouble from poison oak and sunburns, to grumpy bears looking for dinner in your tent. Whether by luck, skill or by spoiling the fun for other campers, be the first to finish your trip and win!

Name: Picture Spot
Description: It's a whole lot of fun trying to match the pieces of the modes of transportation together. Line up the puzzle cards with the right spot on the game board to reveal the whole picture. Children successfully complete the pictures by using visual clues to match the cards to their boards.

Name: Galebari
Description:
From the box cover:
It's summertime at Adriatic coast. Beautiful girls from all over the world came to enjoy sea, sun and good fun. And here they are... who will have more success? Local guys Roko, Stipe, Ante, Borna, Sale... or maybe you?
In this easy learning standalone card game player takes a role of "GALEBAR" - summertime playboy who competes in winning over lady tourists of most intriguing desires. (Based on true stories from Adriatic beaches.)
Deck consists of 94 cards (36 Ladies, 30 Approaches, 11 Places and 17 Events). When a Lady comes into play, each GALEBAR plays one of his available Approaches. Depending on Lady's Interests (Romance, Sex, Fun and Money), active Place and Event, each player counts his score. The player with the highest positive score wins over the Lady. The end winner is the player with the most Ladies won during the game.

Name: Jetzt fahrn wir übern See...
Description:
Jetzt fahrn wir übern See... consists mainly of beautifully designed panels showing a picture that represents a children's song. One card is drawn each round, and the song is sung. The kids try to identify and grab the right tile, and the first one who does so keeps it. Whoever has the most titles at the end of the game wins!

The 2013 edition of Jetzt fahrn wir übern See... includes forty songs, with the complete text of each song.

Name: Jo Müllers Kino Quiz
Description: The players race around the board and answer questions from various movie categories such as Quotes, Cult Cinema, Actors, Genre and so forth. Whenever they get a question right they can mark down points on their marking sheets. However answers a specific number of questions first is the winner. The game comes in a film spool packaging and includes a soundtrack CD over famous movie tunes

Name: Wordigy: A World of Words for Family Fun
Description: There are 130 cards, each with a letter and a value (values range from 1 to 5; the same letter can have different values on different cards).  There are multiple rounds, with the number of cards dealt to each player increasing from 5 to 10 as the game goes along.  Players draw and discard in turn until someone can spell a word using all but one of their cards.

Name: The New York Times Crossword Puzzle Game
Description:
Players take turns solving crossword puzzle clues before their time runs out, and advancing their pegs along a cribbage-style track based on the number of letters that are in the words they have correctly solved.

The puzzles are actual New York Times crossword puzzles, edited by Eugene T. Maleska, having a copyright date of 1978, and there are 100 of them. Additionally there are another 20 "Junior Level" puzzles.

An approximately two-minute hourglass timer provides the suspense, and players select which clues to answer based on the values on four ten-sided dice.

The player who has advanced his pegs furthest along the track  at the end of the game (e.g., when the crossword puzzle is completely solved) is the winner.

Name: B.S.
Description:
B.S. is a trivia game that asks players to distinguish the truth from the total B.S. "Is 'Batonophobia' the fear of cheerleaders?" "Do mice cry tears like humans?"

It is a combination of poker and of straight trivia. Players must determine which of 3 random facts is B.S. and they bet on their answers using poker-style betting chips.

Players can also draw "Total B.S." cards, which ask you to shout of out B.S when you think you know which of 5 statements read in a row is B.S.!

The winner of B.S. is the player with the most chips at the end of the game.

Name: National Geographic: Pictures of the World Card Game
Description: A simple trivia game on the topic of geography using cards with color pictures.

Name: Chalk Talk Hockey Trivia Game
Description:
This action packed Hockey Trivia Game is designed for hockey fans 8-adult. There are over 100 challenging questions on hockey rules and trivia. After landing on ChalkTalk or Locker Room Trivia and answering the question correctly, get ready to take a shot on goal! ChalkTalk's unique patented Mag-Action goal system makes a shot on the goalie a combination of luck and skill. It's an exciting race to put your hockey team together. The first team to have 6 players on their team bench is the winner!
For 2 or more players. Guaranteed Fun and No Skates Required!

Name: Dumbass!
Description:
Dumbass!  is the kissin' cousin of the F*ck This!!  card game, one level more sophisticated and two levels less raunchy (you can actually play it with your family).

Like the various "dumb crook news" stories, each player competes to perform the most inane stunts possible, the winner being the first person to get themselves killed or permanently incarcerated for their stupidity.

In addition, a custom expansion is available, with ten cards, and an  Infinite Armies - like interface that allows you to completely customize each card before printing, allowing you to create a personalized deck with cards indistinguishable from the main game.

Both Dumbass! and the expansion are pdf titles, which are downloaded and printed on cardstock or the pre-perfed business card sheets available at any office supply store.

Expanded By:

    Dumbass! expansion #1

Name: Show Off!
Description:
From back of box:
Players race around the alphabet game board, as they flip over category cards and place their chips on letters. You can only put down a chip if you can name something that begins with the letter that matches the category card in play. You get 1 point for each chip you can place.  Whoever has the most points after 5 rounds wins the game.

There are three different games to play, including an advanced game where players can bluff their way around the board.

Contents include: pencil, score pad, game rules, 6 chip holder boxes, Show Off game board, 100 Show Off category cards, and 180 colored chips in 6 different colors.

Name: Hue Knew?
Description:
From back of box:
Match the color to the word – it's harder than you think!
Think you can think straight? Think again, in this fast-moving, fun-filled game where you have to spot the color name that's written in the correct hue. It's harder than it sounds – and more fun than you ever imagined!

Contents: 40 Hue Knew? disks, Cover disk, and 10 colored pawns.

Name: Timbuktu: Empire in the West African Sudan 1050-1550
Description:
(from page 2 of the rule book)

Timbuktu is a four-player strategic-level wargame simulating the rise and fall of empires in the gold-producing regions of West Africa during the period 1050-1550. Each turn represents fifty years, more than enough time for several changes of monarch. Therefore, players are not taking the part of a king. Instead, they represent the changing political goals of their Tribe’s collective leadership.

Players will quickly realize that this is not a game where one Tribe can build an empire and hold onto it for the length of the game. Historically, as soon as any political system becomes set, decomposition begins. In short, empires decline. The effect of economic inflation and administrative inefficiency is built into the game. Victory lies in creating as glorious an empire as possible and cutting losses when it falls.

Name: A Day at the Races
Description:
A Day at the Races is a novel if somewhat random attempt at creating the excitement of a race meet complete with betting on the family room table.

This game comes from the Crown and Andrews stable well-noted for their tabletop cricket simulation "Test Match" which has stood the test of time as the benchmark children’s cricket game that delivers strategy and fun through a heavily TOY based game. e.g.: manually triggering your bowler to bowl a ball which the batsman needs to manually trigger and hit to toy fieldsmen.

However a Day at the Races involves you clamping one end of the racetrack to the end of your table with two provided metal clamps and then pulling a tensioned green vinyl racetrack out until you can hook it over the other end of the table. Then it is a matter of setting up the other colorful bits such as the starting stalls, the finishing post and of course the five lovely plastic horses complete with weighted swinging jockeys.

Players then present their stall cards to get their starting places and have an opportunity to bet on who they think will hit the finish line first.

From here it is a matter of turning a crank at the starting line which causes the track to vibrate under the horses propelling them slowly forward, until a winner emerges.

As far as I can determine this seems entirely random (although the weighted jockeys seem to behave differently each time). Though the game would be a great beer and pretzels action affair or for those loving horse racing. Due to the random nature and betting I wouldn't really recommend for youngsters.

Name: Fairy Meat: Components Pack
Description: The component pack expansion for Fairy Meat provides additional materials to accommodate up to 8 more players. The bundle contains fairy cards, life counters, twinkle counters, and kill counters for use in the game.

Name: Svenskt brädspel
Description:
Svenskt brädspel (Swedish Tables), more commonly known as just Brädspel or Bräde, is a Backgammon relative native to Sweden. It's the last surviving member of the 17th-century Verkehren/Revertier family of games, that mainly differ from Backgammon in forbidding the closing of the first eleven points - making it possible to win by "locking out" one's opponent, called jan in the Swedish terminology. Brädspel adds to Verkehren a third objective - arranging one's pieces in one of four preset patterns - and rules for hitting a closed point under special circumstances.

A Brädspel table was brought aboard the warship Vasa on her ill-fated maiden voyage in 1628. When the ship was salvaged in 1961, that board rekindled interest in the game, helping it survive where other Verkehren games died out. Today, the game is governed by the Swedish Tables Association of the Vasa Museum, which holds annual championships right next to old Vasa.

RULES: 
(Slight variants may exist. These rules are based on the (lengthier, complete) rules used in the Swedish Championships.)

The game consists of a board (similar to a backgammon board), 15 checkers (game pieces) each of two colours for a total of 30 pieces, and 2 regular dice.
A full match is usually played as best out of a predetermined odd number of games. Winning a single game gives 1-4 points as described below.

The fields are called tongues and are numbered from 1-24 for each player, starting with 1 at the top right tongue as seen from the player, and going counterclockwise around the board with 24 in the lower right corner. Tongue number 1 is called  a player’s ”home” and number 12 is referred to as "huk". Fields 1-6 constitute the first quarter, 7-12 the second, 13-18 the third, and 19-24 the fourth.

Preparations: Each player choses one color and places all his/her 15 checkers on his/her home tongue in the upper, right corner. The starting order for the first game is determined by rolling one die each after which the player with the lowest result goes first. In consecutive games the loser of the previous game starts.

Gameplay: 
The players take turns throwing the dice and (if possible) moving their pieces. The game pieces are moved counter-clockwise according to the dice. If a player is able to make a move it is obligatory to do so. If only one die can be used it is mandatory to do so. The player can choose to move the same piece for both dice or move a different piece for each die. If moving the same piece for both dice it is forbidden to add up the the numbers and land immediately on the field corresponding to the sum. The piece has to be moved first according to either of the dice and then according to the other. If both dice show the same number they are counted double, e.g. if two fives are thrown the player moves 5 + 5 + 5 + 5 steps and the player can distribute these four moves freely on 1-4 game pieces.

There must never be game pieces of opposite colors on the same tongue. A player may have no more than one game piece each on tongues nr 2-11, and once the home has been reduced to one game piece the same applies to that field. On tongues 12-24 the number of the player's own game pieces is unlimited. If a game piece lands on a tongue with a single opponent piece, that piece is ”beaten,” meaning that it is temporarily taken out and has to re-enter the game by landing on a tongue in the first quarter that is either vacant or has a single piece of the opponent’s colour. (See exception under blasting – b below) No other moves are allowed for a player with one or more beaten pieces until they are all back in play.

Two or more pieces of the same colour on a tongue are referred to as bands. A game piece may normally not land on one of the opponent's bands. (Exception explained under ”blasting” a-b below.)

Blasting: 
Though it is not normally allowed to land on a field containing a band of the opposite colour there are two exceptions. Beating more than one piece at once like this is called blasting. 
a) If a player has bands on six or more consequtive fields the opponent may beat all the pieces on one of these fields by landing on it.
b) If the opponent has bands in a player’s first quarter and the player’s only opportunity to get all his beaten pieces back into play is by landing on one or more of the opponent’s bands he is allowed to do so, blasting the opponent’s pieces.
If a player has exited all pieces but one from the game it is no longer allowed to blast with that last piece.

Winning conditions:
There are several different winning conditions (five if counted as below) plus the possibility for a player to surrender a game. A surrendered game gives one point to the winner. A player can surrender at any time as long as he has not yet formed any band in his third or fourth quarter. After doing so surrendering is no longer allowed, even if the band(s) has/have since been broken.

1. "Home play" Exiting the board with all 15 checkers. (1 point for winner)
Once all of a player’s pieces are in the fourth quarter he can start taking them out of the game by throwing at least the number required to reach an imaginary 25th tongue. (If a piece is beaten at this stage it has to re-enter and move all the way into the fourth quarter before any furher pieces of that colour can exit.)

2 ”Beautiful game” (1 point for  winner)
There are four different winning conditions referred to as "beautiful game" which are all obtained by arranging the game pieces in specific patterns in the fourth quarter. They all give one point to the winner. Both dice must be counted, i.e. a player can not win this way by only moving for one of the two numbers thrown. However, if a player can win through ”beautiful game” by casting one die only he may chose to do so. In case of failiure he may only cast one die on each of his two following turns. The four variants of beautiful game are:
2a. Three pieces each on tongues 20-24 
2b. Five pieces each on tongues 22-24
2c. Three pieces on tongue 22, five pieces on tonge 23, and seven pieces on tongue 24
2d. All fifteen pieces on tongue 24.

3. "Monk" (2 points for winner)
3a) ”Homeplay with monk" Winning by homeplay while the opponent has at least one beaten checker not yet back into gameplay.
3b) "Beautiful game with monk" Winning by beautiful game while the opponent has at least one beaten checker not yet back into gameplay.

4. "Jan" (2 points for winner)
If a player beats more of the opponent’s pieces than can possibly re-enter the game (due to a lack of available tongues in the first quarter) that player wins the game. This is called ”making the opponent Jan”

5. "Blast-Jan" (4 points for winner) 
Making the opponent Jan by blasting a band.

Name: Talstafet
Description: The game consists of: 1 board, 1 red die, 1 blue die, 1 playing piece, 35 number tokens, 1 set of rules. The one who gathers most points wins. Move a playing piece around the board and get as many number tokens as possible before the board is out of tokens or your piece cannot move anymore.

Name: Ordfejden
Description:
Ordfejden, Swedish for "the word feud", is a dice based crossword game by the Swedish snack-company OLW. Including timer, 15 dice, score sheets and rules it was given away as a freebie when buying two packs of OLW snacks.

Ordfejden is a word dice game.

Name: Futbol Cacho
Description:
This a little dice game that we play in our town (Oruro, Bolivia), the popular name is Capi Futbol because it's based on another dice game called Capi Manda (or The Captain give orders) that is kind of like poker dice...

In order to play you just need 5 dice, a cup, and you have to draw a sketch of a football pitch (divided in 5 areas: goal area - field - midfield (the mid line does is not a divisor line) - field - goal area) and a counter that represent the ball (we almost always use a bottle cap).

The game starts with the "ball" at midfield. After a "toss" the one who has the kick off shakes the dice in the cup and the other player does the same (always after the one who is the Captain at time), then the non-captain player can re-roll from 1 to 5 dice, after he does the captain can do the same, they both can no use the re roll (see SIT DOWN below).

This way they play "poker hands" with rankings like this: 5 same (Grande), 1 different (Poker), 2 same 3 same (Full House), 1,2,3,4,5 or 2,3,4,5,6 or 3,4,5,6,1 (Escaleras, in ties the higher straight wins, 3 of the same (Tricas, 111 the higher, 222 the lowest), pairs, if neither of you has anything then both players put all the 5 dice in their cup and play simultaneously with no re-rolls with highest winning.

Every time a player wins a hand, he moves the ball one space towards the opponents goal area.

When you are playing in the goal area if the Attacking player wins it's a goal, you can play to a certain amount of goals,or with a time limit.

suggested optional rules.
 DESPEJE (Shot from the goal keeper) after winning a hand in his own goal area a player may choose to made a Despeje.

If he does he rolls one die and moves the number of pips in spaces towards the Goal area of the opponent, but when it reaches the goal area then the ball goes back towards the field (some people choose to not let the ball go back to the goal area or field of the shooter).

After this shot the opponent keeps possession and is now the Captain).

SIT DOWN (Mid distance shot at the goal) there is no re roll if you are in the "Field" area next to your opponent's Goal area, if the attacker wins its a goal (some people prefer to Announce the shot before a SIT DOWN happens), if the defender wins it's a DESPEJE but this time the defender keeps control after the play.


3 LINEUP CHANGES to represent the 3 substitutions of players allowed in a football match, the player can Voltear (turn a dice over to its opposite side) 3 times in a match (i.e. a 3 can become a 4 if using a change, a 2 can become a 5, a 6 can become a 1 etc.) Some people let the attacking player do 1 Volteo each hand if he desires except when he is at the opponent's Goal area.

Well this game is fun and you can play it anywhere  (because it is a modified game of Generala it's like our national game) and of course it's about luck but not pure luck.

Name: Conjecture for Kids
Description:
The "model" game for enhancing a child’s creativity. Based on the best-selling original Conjecture, Conjecture For Kids is designed for younger players. The object of the game is to sculpt modeling dough into a topic identified on your game card in hopes that your team can guess the right answer before your opponents.

This game offers parents and teachers a wonderful tool to help children develop hand-eye coordination, and teach them to associate imagery with words.

Similar to the classic game of Pictionary, only using sculpting dough rather than drawings, Conjecture For Kids offers hours of entertainment for parties of all sizes. To assist the artistically-challenged, we permit the sculptor to make motions with the dough, however noises (aside from laughter) are forbidden.

The hilarious game features two varieties of uniquely scented dough that will last several years if maintained properly, and because it is water based, it won’t make a mess.
Families: Versions & Editions: Junior Versions of Grown-Up Games

Name: Sudoku Taisen 6x6: The Great Battle of Sudoku
Description:
Taisen, a Japanese word for Great Battle. Now you know ... But are you ready? Are you ready for the Great Battle of Sudoku!

Sudoku Taisen is a true multi-player sudoku game.  6x6 grid with 1,000+ ways to play and you are the puzzle!

In Sudoku Taisen 6x6, it is much more challenging to complete your grid because you are sharing 8 squares (shared squares are called Taisen Square) with your opponent(s). Your opponents can place a number to prevent you from completing your grid. Therefore, you need to stack your opponent's number with your desired number, so you may complete your grid. Your opponents will surely do the same to you. Furthermore, additional challenge, your fate of winning also depends on your dice roll and the Taisen Card you draw.

Contents:
20 Taisen Cards
180 Chips
1 Die
1 Board (two sides)
1 Manual in English

Board is designed for two or four players. It can also be used for one player and three players.

Related to:

    Sudoku Taisen 4x4: The Great Battle of Sudoku

Name: Complete Tiddledy Winks
Description:
This is a deluxe version of Tiddeldy Winks with a bowling variant.

It can be played as the regular game in which players try to be the first to snap all three of their winks into the cup.

Or the Target Tiddeldy Winks variant can be played using the target board and cup, which are neatly set into the box bottom so that the cup is roughly flush with the target surface.  In this variation the first player to 100 points wins, with higher points being achieved by the concentric rings of the target or the cup itself.

The Tiddeldy Winks Bowling game is what makes this unique.  In this variation the target/cup remains in the box, but a cover is placed on the cup.  Atop that cover sits a red bowling pin with a separate wide circular base.  Nine white pins are placed on the marked circles around it, forming the ten pins of a standard triangular bowling arrangement.

Players try to snap their winks and down the pins.  Ten points are awarded for the red pin, and one for each of the white pins.  The player with the highest total after ten rounds of three winks snapped wins the game.

Name: Boar Hunt: The Dark Ages
Description:
Boar Hunt:The Dark Ages Game is a game that appears simple at first glance because there are only 9 spots on the board and 8 playing pieces which all remain on the board during the game after they've been placed.

Boar Hunt has two teams of 3 Dark Ages "Hunters" and a "Wild Boar". One player plays the red set and the other plays the white set. The object of the game is to be the first player to capture their "Boar" between 2 of their "Hunters" either going across the board or along the outside circle.

The game is played in 2 phases as in a 9-Mans Morris Game. The players take turns placing their Boars and Hunters on the board and if no one wins in the placement phase, the players take turns moving their pieces to capture their own Boar between their own Hunters while trying to block their opponent from winning.

Though there have been countless games through the centuries which use a small format game board (Mu Torere and TicTacToe to name 2)but Boar Hunt is the first that uses 2 teams trying to achieve different but similar goals.

Boar Hunt:The Dark Ages Game started out as a small game with a leather "Acorn" board with glass playing pieces packaged in an attractive wood box.

The deluxe version features a solid wood game board with nice details and the playing surface is burnt into the wood using the "pyrography" decorating technique. The playing pieces are hand finished castings of the original playing pieces which look like they were carved in the actual Dark Ages. The playing pieces have a nice heft to them and the game is quite attractive when set up.

The size of the board (6"x9"x3/4" - 16cm x 23cm x 2cm)and the sculptural quality of the playing pieces will make this an attractive game to leave set up on your desk, coffee table or bookshelf.

Name: Sebastopols Belägring
Description:
SEBASTOPOLS BELÄGRING. Nytt slags schackspel.
Ett underhållande tidsfördrif för ungdom och i sällskapskretsar.
Detta nya spel bildar en övergång från Dam- till Schackspelet samt ger eger ökadt intresse genom att bildlikt framställa den krigsskådeplats, som fortfarande tager vår samtids hela uppmärksamhet i anspråk.

Nytryck 2001, Armémuseum Stockholm.

THE SIEGE OF SEBASTOPOL. New kind of Chess.
A amusing pastime for youth and society.
This new game is a link from Checker to Chess and tries to visualize the battleground, that still claim all our society's attention.

New print 2001, The Swedish army museum Stockholm.

Name: Games of the World
Description:
GAMES of the WORLD has been Chris's pet project at Acorn Games for years. Acorn Games has always wanted to produce a game with a solid wood board and playing pieces that allow you to play a multitude of games. They have gathered together four classic games from around the world and have designed four of their own games that can all be played on a classic "Alquerque" board.

They found some games which use 12 or less pieces of each color that can all be played on the same board. Next they set out to design a series of new games which use the same pieces and board but have either more modern moves or conditions of victory to make them appeal to today’s game players.

The classic games that you will find in the book are;

Alquerque("Alquerque" is a Checkers variant) from Spain
Seega("Seega") from Africa and Egypt
Cercar La Liebre(similar to "Catch the Hare") also from Spain
Five Field Kono("Five Field Kono") from Korea

The new games from Acorn Games in the book are;

"Fortress", a "condition" game
"Centaurs", a "replacement" game
"Troop", another replacement game
"Neutrino", another condition game

In a "Replacement Game" the players are each trying to get from
their starting point to where their opponent started out from.
Sort of like in "Chinese Checkers"

In a "Condition Game" the players
are trying to be the first player to DO something. This may be to
get something like getting 3-in-a-row as in TicTacToe but not
mattering WHERE on the board you achieve this.

Solid wood construction and pieces as well as a clearly written rule book with diagrams make this a sure bet with teachers and game players alike.

Not described but playable with the included board of the board game collection as well: "Bagh Bandi", Bagh Chal from Nepal, and Fanorona Dimy (a Fanorona variant on a five times five board) from Madagascar. Rules available in BGG.

Name: MadWish
Description:
MadWish is an  electrifying party game which will make all your MAD wishes come true. MadWish  combines the best drinking elements with flirting and snitching co-players. Playing MadWish with friends will guarantee a hilarious night never to be forgotten.

A wheel of fortune game which should play at its best when there is an equal number of male and female players playing. There are things you have to do and truths you have to tell during the game and your aim is to gather the predetermined amount of money before others do. A thing you must do in the course of the game could be for example sending an SMS to your ex claiming that he or she really is lousy in bed...

Name: Clone
Description:
From back of box:

Clone is a challenging new game that combines skill and luck on a unique battlefield.  The objective is to attack and eliminate your opponent's forces and prevent them from cloning lost pieces by destroying their cloning stations.  Whether advancing your forces across the board into enemy territories or beaming them directory into any territory via transport stations, you'll find 'Clone' to be a game that will bring hours of fun for family and friends.

Owner's description:

A six sided board with locations for cloning stations on the outside and transportation portals on the inside with hex spaces between.  Each player plays one (or more) color and has 6 cloning stations and 6 playing pieces.  Playing pieces have different values (2 each of one, two and three) and can only capture those of like value or below (a la Stratego).

Three different six-sided dice control your possible choices for action each turn.  The 'Movement' die is numbered 1-2-3-1-2-3 and controls how far you can move and how large a piece you may clone each turn.  The 'Clone' die with 5 blank sides and 'Clone' printed on the remaining side determines whether you can bring a captured piece back and also allows you to roll again.  The remaining 'Control' die determines what combination of actions you may take: Attack, Teleport, enter or exit a Cloning Station.

Name: Daler
Description: In  the year 1613 The Danish King Christian IV forbade cursing  and gaming. Daler is one of the games which was played at open seas behind the canons of the ship, because the gamblers were afraid of getting caught in the act. The game is a simple dice game for gamblers.

Name: Crash and Scramble
Description: In their attempt to continue to offer sport games that are not-so-ordinary PLAAY games released Crash and Scramble as one of their last release before their demise. Crash and Scramble brought the fury that is professional Lacrosse to the gaming table.

Name: First Contact: YOUR TOWN
Description:
What if intelligent beings from another planet decided to forcibly take possession of planet Earth by taking over people's bodies? And what if the place they landed to begin implementation of this takeover was YOUR TOWN? And...what if YOU were the only one who KNEW about it?

PLAAY's venture into the non-sports arena had them hosting an invasion of Earth.  The game boasted as many of theirs did a solid solitaire game system.

Name: Heroes of Might and Magic V Collectible Card and Tile Game
Description:
The second demon war is at hand! the epic battle between Haven and Inferno reignites with this spectacular translation of Ubisoft's brand new release, Heroes of Might and Magic V. Choose a side in the primary clash or elect a separate path by hoisting the flag of the Necropolis, Academy, Dungeon or Sylvan forces.

This 3rd volume in DGA's Ultimate Fantasy Wargame series will keep you and your friends captivated for hours each time you break open the box!


    from DGAGAMES website*


With a similar game system to Heroes of Might and Magic IV CTG, the differences mirror those of the computer game series.  See for yourself the immense difference it makes when  your armies MUST be lead by Heroes-Heroes who cannot be directly targeted in battle.  Fans of the ever popular Heroes of Might and Magic III will be pleasantly surprised with the similarities in both style and content.
Families: Video Game Theme: Heroes of Might & Magic

Name: Hop Little Frog
Description:
One day four hungry frogs went hunting. When they got to the edge of the pond nearby, they each spotted a fly on the other side that they wanted to catch. The only problem was how they would get to the other side? They thought that a path of lily pads pads would be the answer, but there were not enough lily pads to go around. Their problem can be solved with the help of the die, so join them and catch the fly!

In Hop Little Frog, the frogs hop across the pond to catch the flies, but to do so they must first of all "make the lily pads grow".

Name: Lion of Ethiopia: Tiger of Ethiopia
Description:
Tiger of Ethiopia was published in Command Magazine 6 and is a variant of Lion of Ethiopia (published in Command Magazine 4 which is required in order to play this variant).

In this alternate history, Nazi Germany and Japan were victorious in WW II have turned on each other to start WWW III in 1948. This game deals with the Japanese invasion of the Horn of Africa as a southern pincer to Black Gold (a stand-alone game published separately along with Mississippi Banzai), to tear the entire Middle East away from German/Italian control. Japanese have air superiority, the first Japanese tank army, Andean mountain units and Ethiopian guerrillas and other Japanese units against the Italian Army (same units as the Italian army of 1936 in Lion of Ethiopia). The Afrika Korps, British SS legions and Arab SS cavalry legions enter as reinforcements.

One 22" x 34" map. 
Divisional level with a few brigades/regiments/battalions.

Name: Polus
Description: A challenging dice game for 2-6 players: The players take turns to roll two dice each; every player may use 3 dice rolls at the most to get 5, 10, 15, 20 or 25 points for the round. The player who reaches 100 first wins the game.

Name: Ultra Quick Tennis
Description:
From the Publisher's website:

Announcing Ultra-Quick Tennis!

My goal in designing this game was to develop a mechanism to quickly play through a tennis tournament. With other tennis games, either the game took too long to realistically complete a full tournament, or the game was too simplistic and produced far too many upsets. As with all of my games, I wanted a quick playing design that closely mirrored reality in the tennis world. The end result is a game that I´m very proud of.

Ultra-Quick Tennis has been thoroughly tested for statistical accuracy. I am extremely confident that the formulas employed in the game accurately represent each player. To make it a game, I´ve added some elements of chance, as well as some rare play results. Overall, I think you´ll find the winners to be on par with what you would reasonably expect.

Ultra Quick Tennis includes over 300 professional men from the 2005 ATP Tour and well over 400 professional women from the 2005 WTA Tour. Also included are the full schedules for both Tours.

Players are accurately rated for each playing surface found on the respective Tours. You'll experience the sheer dominance of Roger Federer on grass. Clay court specialists like Guillermo Coria will shine at Roland Garros, but prove to be mortal on the hard courts at the US Open. Every player will realistically perform as they did in actual tennis competition during the 2005 campaign.

All of the unusual events that can happen in tennis like injuries, retirements, loss of concentration, arguing line calls all happen in Ultra Quick Tennis as well. The ball is in your court, purchase Ultra Quick Tennis today!

Name: Ultra Quick Football
Description:
From the publisher's website:

Ultra Quick Football provides you with over 600 teams from the 2004-04 collegiate season. All teams from Division 1A to Division III are rated. UQ Football also provides you with the 2004-05 NFL Season, 2004 Canadian Football League, 2004 NFL Europe, and the 2004-05 Arena Football League.

No other game provides you with as many teams in one package!

As with our entire Ultra Quick lineup, individual games play in seconds. With Ultra Quick Football, you can easily play out a team's entire season in one sitting. You can play an entire league in hours, rather than days, weeks, months or years like other games.

In ultra Quick Football, all teams are rated for Offensive Ability, Defensive Ability, and Home Field Advantage. The NFL is also rated for Home Field Advantage in Playoff games. The College teams are rated for Strength of Schedule, so you can accurately match up any two teams.

Get on the field today with Ultra Quick Football!

Name: Bulyah
Description:
Armed with the beverage of their choice, players of BULYAH take turns rolling dice and moving around the board, trying to collect enough Letter Cards to spell the word, "BULYAH."  In true board game fashion, there are stops along the way that try to prevent players from reaching their goal.  These stops are what make the game interesting  and bring the drinking into the picture.

Before play begins, a 4-ounce glass is filled to the brim with the beverage of everyone’s choice and is placed in the middle of the board. The "Grave" will be consumed many times throughout the game, as players either land on a "Grave Stone" space on the board or are instructed to do so by one of the 100 Action Cards.  When an Action Card is drawn, the player must follow the command designated.  These can range from announcing, "I am stupid" before taking a drink, to revealing one of your most embarrassing moments, to acting as servant to all of the other players by refilling their drinks, and even making up your own rule as the "Rule Master." Oh yeah, be weary of the Prison and Hospital spaces, however, you can gain relief by hiding out in the "Safety Zone".

Contents: One party board, 100 Action cards, 60 Letter cards, two die, and six tokens.

Name: Epées Royales
Description:
Second volume in the "Au fil de l'Epée" series.
It covers 4 Medieval battles: Bremule, Taillebourg, Mons-en-Pevele ,and Cassel.

The game has high quality color components: 
- Rulebook (8 color pages)
- Historical and scenario booklet (14 color pages)
- 3 token sheets to be mounted (415 token)
- 4 maps (2 A3 format and 2 A3x2).
- Available in English or French
Families: Series: Au Fil de l'Épée (Frédéric Bey)

Name: Batman
Description: Based on the comic book of the 70's, Batman by Hasbro is an exciting crime fighting game where you play the dynamic duo. Gotham's evilest criminals have run amok in the city and it's up to Batman and Robin to capture them and return then to the Bat Cave.

Name: Murder à la carte: Eat, Drink, and Be Married
Description:
The mystery: Welcome to Vegas with it's glitzy casinos and show-stopping entertainment. The deck is stacked against wealthy casino owner, Blackjack White, as he bursts into the love-me chapel to stop his beautiful naive daughter from marrying a burly biker named Ezekiel Z. Ryder. Alas, Blackjack is shot dead by a member of the wedding party. Don't bet on the guilty suspect...it may be you...

Includes party planner, character booklets for all suspects including their roles and background information, 8 place cards, 8 party invitations & envelopes, 6 secret clues, and cassette tape with an introduction, summary of events, and the solution to the crime.

Name: Branson the Game
Description:
Take a vacation to Branson, Missouri. While playing the game, players roll dice, move around the floor, and collect as many Vacation Cards as possible. At the end of thirty minutes, the player with the most Vacation Cards is the winner. 
Vacation Cards include Show-Time Cards, Meal-Time Cards and Fun-Time Cards. There are also Action Cards which include Think-Fast Cards, Audition Cards and Good News/Bad News Cards. Side loop trips also offered on the game board. 
Very colorful board with playing pieces in the shapes of little family sedans. The good news: no money involved.
BONUS: This is a virtual time capsule of Branson in 1992. Many of the attractions and stars featured on the game board are no longer in Branson or have passed away. Includes Boxcar Willie, John Davidson, Wayne Newton, Tony Orlando, Ray Stevens, Jim Stafford and more!

Name: Kort Alfapet
Description: KortAlfapet is a card variant of ALGAs Alfapet. Try to lay out as long words as you can with the cards in your hand, to get as many points as possible.

Name: Battle for Tromaville
Description:
Dr. Killernoff, the pollution breathing alien from the planet Smogular, has come to Tromaville. Unless we team up with Toxie and the Good Guys, Tromaville is doomed. Apocalypse, Inc. and the Bad Guys are out to destroy us! Let's go get 'em!

Objective of the game is to be the first player to travel the board and get back safely to Toxie's headquarters.

You become one of the Toxic Crusaders as you travel the path through Tromaville. You will battle the sinister Bad Guy cards with Toxic Crusaders Good Guy cards. You'll be challenged to fight the pollutant mutants of Apocalypse Inc. wherever they spread toxic disaster.
 On each turn, players move along the game path. The path leads through six endangered areas of Tromaville. Players battle the Bad Guys and clean up Bad stuff as they follow instructions on the game board. The first player to reach Toxerific is the winner.

Ages 6 and up

Name: Gosix
Description:
Gosix is an abstract strategy game played on a 7 hexagons board.  You're trying to control 4 of the 7 hexagons. The trick is: whenever you get control over a hexagon, you lose some of the pawns that made you win.

Players take turns placing a pawn on the board. You must discover how to win while losing as few pawns as possible, or "help" your opponent to win and have him lose as many pawns as possible.

Name: Clobber
Description:
Clobber is played by two players, White and Black, on a rectangular 
checkerboard, often of size n*(n+1) for some n. However, in the Computer
Olympiads Clobber is played on 10x10-boards.

In the initial position, all squares are occupied by a stone, with white stones on the white squares and black stones on the black squares. A player moves by picking up one of their stones and "clobbering" an opponent's stone on an adjacent square (horizontally or vertically).
The "clobbered" stone is removed from the board and replaced by the stone that was moved. The game ends when one player, on their turn, is unable to move, and then that player loses.

Name: Nazca
Description: The lines on the floor of the Nazca Valley in the Peruvian Andes have mystified us since their discovery in the early years of the last century.  In this game, you assume the role of a Nazca village leader, managing your villagers and assigning them to tasks.  The rewards of these labors are the resources you need to build the legendary Nazca Lines.

Name: Buck Rogers Game: Adventures in the 25th Century
Description:
From the box:

Join Captain Buck Rogers and Colonel Wilma Deering, commander of the Intercept Squadron, as they blast off from Earth to battle marauding space pirates. Take over the Draconian flagship, the pirates' base, and halt the invasion.

The game is based off the early 80s TV show of the same name.

According to daVinci editrice (online): "you just have to follow the instructions on two disks (one to determine the movements of the ships, and the other one for the actions to make when two ships are in the same point). The object of the game is to be the first player (there can be 2-4 of them) to board the Draconian ship with both his ships, that have to be moved from one side to the other of the board."

Name: The Game of Mythology
Description:
An instructional card game meant to teach players the names, history, functions, and associations of characters and locations in classical mythology.

The game is played with 76 different cards, which each tell the story of a different mythological figure.

Included is a pronunciation card, a 2-sided instruction card, and a 4 pages "background" by "the compiler": Laura Wheaton Abbot Cooke, Chicago, Ill., March 1884.

The object of the game is to collect the cards into "books" (melds). The one who collects the greatest number of books wins the game.

A book is composed of five specific cards (i.e. Jupiter - the number 1 card- +Saturn + Neptune + Rhea + Ceres). A typical card from the deck shows the name of a god, a small illustration of the god, the names of the four other gods which form a book, and (the largest section) a History, which is not used in game play. Note that the cards are in black and white, so the books lack the modern convenience of color-matching borders.

There are also a couple of "location" cards which have special effects.

Name: Trezo
Description: Using a game board of 27 spaces and 27 unique playing pieces, players try to form a group of three pieces with a like attribute (color, height, shape) or three pieces with no matching attribute.  Each piece has one of three attributes in each of three categories - Color (red, green or yellow), Height (short, medium or tall) and Shape (square, triangle, circle).

Name: The Glass Bead Game
Description:
The Glass Bead Game was created by the Dutch game inventor Christian Freeling in the late 1970s. It was named after the final novel of the German writer Hermann Hesse which was published in 1943 ("Das Glasperlenspiel"). Hesse was put on the Black List of the Nazis while living as a refugee in Switzerland. After continental Europe was liberated, Hesse was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1946. Freeling's game is one of many conceptualizations that were inspired by Hesse's novel.

The game differs from most traditional Mancala games in having counters with different values. Another unusual concept of the game is that there are two types of capturing (direct and indirect). The game can be played online at Freeling's homepage.
